title: I am an only child and sole beneficiery to my parents trust and wills. I am also trustee. How do I terminate the trust now?
question: My parents are both gone now, we have two properties and a car under the trust name, plus a couple of annuities. Do they stay that way?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Wills and estates,Estates,Estate property,Wills,Trusts,Trustee,Trust beneficiaries
answers:
It all depends on the terms of the trust instrument. If the trust provides that upon the death of the last to die of your parents the assets are to be distributed to you, then you can transfer the properties now. The real estate can be transfered to you by a deed from you as trustee to you; the annuities can be transfered through the insurance companies and the car though the DMV. If the terms of the trust provide for a later transfer to the benefiriaries, then you have to follow the trust provisons.

Based on what you said, all of the property will ultimately flow to you. But, how it gets there will depend on how the property is titled. Some assets might flow through the will, others through the trust, and still others by beneficiary designation. One thing I always say when there is a trust is that your primary obligation is to do what the trust says - even if you are the only beneficiary.

A big concern for someone in your situation is making sure that all debts and taxes are resolved as part of the administration. The key benefit of a proper administration is the peace of mind that comes from knowing that everything is taken care of with no loose strings.

Odds are, you could probably do this without an attorney's assistance. However, I also think that an attorney might more than pay for himself/herself in reduced taxes, costs, claims and other avoided headaches.

Find an attorney in your area who offers free consultations and see what they have to say. (I would be glad to meet with you, but I'm not exactly down the street, either.)
